Overview Tour
When you first log into the portal a pop-up will appear to take a “tour “of the portal. You can exit out of the tour at any point and re-start the tour by clicking the ‘Start Tour’ button. 

Once the tour has started click ‘Next’ to progress or ‘Exit’ to stop the tour.

In this tab you can view all dimension results.

text:
Manage Reports- Report Library
In the Report Library you can view all pre-generated reports (based on access permissions), as well as view any custom reports you have generated.

To send a report to another person via the portal, select the report(s) by checking the box next to the report name(s), then click here to search for and choose the recipient. The recipient must already have access to the portal.
Filter using the column headers by clicking on the arrows.
Search for a report by typing the name in the search field. Partial name searches work best.
Click to expand the report to view groups included in the report.
Click to download the PowerPoint Report.
Click to go to the Dashboard and view results for this report.
Refresh the Report Library view.

text:
Action Planning- New Action Planning
Create Actions for yourself or others based on access. 

Option 1: Choose actions from the Suggested Priorities that are pre-populated.
Option 2: Choose action based on All Survey items. Suggested priority actions will show a star next to them.
Option 3: (**If present) Choose from company wide Required Items. 

Once you select an item more options will appear underneath. 
A. Action Ideas to choose from/help guide you. If you select one, it will pre-populate in the open text box.
B. Write in and describe your planned actions or add to the Action Idea.
C. Create a Target Completion date by using the calendar pop up.
D. Choose from the Reminder Type options
E. Choose the action plans Status.
F. Click ‘Save and Finish’ or ‘Save and Add Another’ when done.
G. You can also use the ‘Clear Action’ button to start again.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Welcome to the org vitality reporting portal.  I'm going to walk you through all of the features available for a super user.  First thing to do at the top bar is to select the user you want to view results for.  Here we're looking at Talia Holiday.  If I press the arrow to the right and expand Talia's hierarchy,  here I can see each of the directory ports underneath her.  I can select any of these people by clicking view.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: I can also build out the hierarchy by clicking on the arrows under the folks underneath Talia.  I can build out the hierarchy this way,  or I can type in a name at the top to search for the manager I want to view.  If you are a manager, there will just be one name, your name listed that you can view.  If you're a manager of managers, you will have managers underneath you that you can use.  You can select to view any manager that reports to you.  You cannot view results of anyone who is your peer or above you.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Once you select where in the hierarchy you want to look, the dashboard will populate.  If all you want to do is download your PowerPoint report,  you can click download full report and that will download the PowerPoint to your desktop.  If you want to filter by demographics and you have access to them,  you can click demographic filter here.  On the right, that will pop up some different demographic options.  These all come from your HRIS file or feed.  You can do a combination of ands and ors here between the different variables  and as long as the responses meet minimum and the dashboard will populate with those responses.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If by any chance you click a combination that does not meet minimum and the tool that you want to use  will not return any data in order to protect confidentiality.  At this point, you will have selected the data to look at responses for  and the dashboard will populate with the scores.  So scrolling on down, the overview will have a set of data that's going to help you  understand the overall highs and lows, strengths and opportunities and where you might focus.  These boxes across the top are the dimensions on the survey.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: You can use the arrow on the right or left to scroll through.  If you click on any one of these dimensions, you'll see the box below will populate with the items in that dimension.  So for example, if I click this box on capabilities, the box below will then show all of the items in the capabilities dimension.  In the dimension box, you'll see the percent favorable as well as response count and any comparisons.  And then in the items box, you'll see each individual item along with the response count percent favorable.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If you hover over that percent favorable, you'll also see the number of responses that were favorable as well as comparisons.  Comparisons might be versus trend versus overall or depending on your company, it might be versus business unit or something like that.  You'll notice some of the scores show comparison.  You'll notice some of the scores show comparisons in black text and some are in green or red.  If a difference is not statistically significant, it will be in black text with no arrows.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If it is a statistically significant increase, it will be in green with an up arrow.  If it's a statistically significant decrease, it will be in red with a down arrow.  What's statistically significant that depends on the size of both groups.  If you have more than 100 folks in both groups, you need five points or more difference for it to be statistically significant.  If you have 50 to 99, it needs to be 10 points.  And if it is less than 50 folks, then it needs to be 15 points.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: And that's just because as those groups get smaller, each employee can move the score around a little bit more.  On the right side of the screen, under who responded, you'll see your response rate.  So you'll see the response rate as well as the response count and headcount.  What's a good response rate? Typically over 75% is a good response rate.  At that response rate, we say that that's statistically representative of all the folks in your organization.  And most folks will be able to get a report and meet minimum end.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Underneath that, I can start to build out some of these modules.  You'll see things like most favorable items.  You might see the percent favorable or percent favorable neutral and unfavorable.  These can help you look at your overall strengths and then here are the most unfavorable items.  That's going to be an opportunity.  Anywhere where you see these three dots in the top right corner, if you click those, you can either download an Excel report of the data or you can take a screenshot of the data to use the graphs.  I find this really useful when I'm creating leader presentations.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If you keep scrolling down, what improved the most?  This will be where you have the most improvements on your data if you have a trend and what declined the most.  Same thing. In this example here, it shows insufficient data because there weren't items that declined.  So if that appears in your data, that's just because there weren't relevant items to share.  So this site has shown you overall strengths and opportunities in terms of what's high, low, what's improved in decline.  On the left side, if we start to build out this module, where should I take action?

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: That's going to help you decide where you might focus your improvement efforts.  So here are three items that are specific to you.  These three items are determined by our algorithm, not just what's higher or low, but what is strategically important and what can you have most impact on.  So for me, based on my results, these are the three items that the algorithm is suggesting.  If I hit start action plan, that'll take us to our action tool.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Here I can look at any of the three items and I could also move over to all items if I wanted to work on something else.  But let's say I want to work on this top item here.  If I select it and scroll down, then I'll have some sample action ideas.  If I click a sample action idea, it'll appear in the actions to address, and then I can continue to edit or write a new action plan for how I'm going to address this item.  Underneath that box, I can give it a target completion date.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Make sure you give yourself enough time.  I can set reminders for myself in the tool and set a status, and then I'll hit save and finish.  Here I can review and update any of my actions.  If I wanted to go back in and edit the action once I've been working on it or set some new reminders, I can do that.  And if I'm a manager of managers, I could review other actions.  Here's where I could see any of the actions that folks reporting to me are taking.  You'll see in this table, I can sort by the manager name who's working on the action, the item they're working on, or the action themselves, as well as the target date and status.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Again, you'll see these three dots at the top right.  I can export this to Excel.  I'm going to head back to the dashboard.  Two more things here on the dashboard.  One is the drivers of engagement.  You'll notice these questions are predictive of what makes an employee engaged in your organization.  So these items are the same drivers for everyone in the organization, but they are specific to your organization.  And these are your scores showing here.  So if you want to improve engagement, these are some actionable items to work on.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: And then on the left side, which comments to read, this is where I can select which open-ended comments I want to view and click Read the Highlights in order to get the most actionable comments.  So that's the dashboard to give you an overall sense of how you're doing.  To dig in a little further, you might then click on dimensions.  So remember, dimensions are going to be an average score.  So if I was to look at the alignment dimension, that would be the average of all of the questions about alignment.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: So if I click on the down arrow next to alignment, I can see each of the questions in the alignment dimension.  So I can see how that overall average score for alignment comes together.  I can sort by percent favorable, neutral, unfavorable, response count.  You'll see I have trend versus overall and versus benchmark.  All of these are sortable and filterable.  And if I move over to the questions tab, I can do the same thing.  So I can view any of the questions from the survey.  I can sort up and down based on score as well as comparisons.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Some folks might ask, what's a good score?  Generally, a score of 75% favorable or higher is a strength and a score of 50% favorable or lower is an opportunity.  Now that will, of course, depend on your organization as well as the topic.  Be sure to also focus on what's most important.  Something like 50% favorable on safety is much different than 50% favorable on communication.  Make sure to focus on the things that are really critical for your business.  Moving on from the questions to the heat map, here's one way that you can slice and dice a lot of the data.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: So it will default to a hierarchy view.  So here on the left, we'll see the organization overall and then each of the CEO's direct reports.  You'll see that the scores are color coded.  Green scores are strengths and those that are in red are opportunities.  We can also put it on meaningful differences and where a score is meaningfully different than the overall.  The arrows note where there is significant trend.  I can also expand any of these dimensions to see the questions within.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If I want to go beyond the hierarchy view and look at some demographics, I can click on the demographic dropdown.  For example, click gender and it will cut my data by gender and I can compare here.  Again, these three dots at the top right will allow me to download an Excel report or take a screenshot of the data.  So these are different ways to view the data as it is.  We can also look at different ways to create custom reports.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Before that, we'll go to the report library to see where existing reports are.  So at the very top of the screen, we'll go to manage reports report library and here's where you can see the repository of reports that already exist.  So if there is a particular leader report you're looking for, you can search for the name and then download the PowerPoint report by clicking the PowerPoint icon or you can click on the dashboard icon to view the data on the dashboard.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: If you'd like to create a custom report, we'll start by creating a custom data group. So we'll go to explore data groups, create custom data group, and here you can create a report with any combination of includes or excludes using hierarchy, demographics, or survey items.  I'll start by using Talia as our included manager. So I'll click on her name, drag it over to included managers. I can select normal rollup, directs only rollup including manager or individual.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Make sure that any combination you use will meet minimum end.  And let's say I want to exclude Andy's group because they operate a little differently. I'll drag his name over to exclude.  You'll see a total response counter at the top right to make sure that the group you're building is as intended.  Then I'm going to come over to the left and hit demographics and let's say I wanted to slice by high potential. I'll build out high potential and drag over the group that says ready into included demographics.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: I'll give this group a name at the top in the search bar. I'm going to type in their name. So this is Talia minus Andy high potential.  I'll hit save and that's going to take me to my data group library. Here I'll see all of the data groups that already exist. Those would be the standard data groups that I can sort by type and then the custom data groups that I've built here.  Once I'm here in the custom data group library, I can select any number of data groups and by using the boxes on the far left.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: And then I can click this blue button at the top and I can export them to Excel. I can share them with other group other users in the tool or I can create a report.  I'm going to click create report. It will take me to this screen here. It will show the data groups. I've already selected on the right and if it will show all available data groups on the left.  If there are other data groups I want to include in my report, I can click and drag them over to the right.  I need to select a data group as my primary data group by checking the box under primary. Then I give the data group a name.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Hit save and it will take me back to my data group or to my report library where all of my reports are. You'll see I can sort by customer standard reports and similar to the data group library.  If I select any reports on the left, I can either download them or I can share them with other users in the tool.  Now that we've talked about creating different reports, let's look at different ways to support action.  So if I click action planning at the top right, there are a few different things I can do. The first thing is new action planning.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: We saw this screen a little bit earlier, how you can log in action for yourself. If you are a manager of others or a HR leader, you can also log in action for someone else.  So here it says managing actions for. You can click this down arrow and you can click another user to log in action for if that's something you'd like to do.  Another thing you can do is click the support others function. This is where you can view and support the action plans that are happening throughout the organization.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: So the first dashboard you see will be overall metrics on what's happening. The one on the far left report downloads by manager.  This is just who's downloaded or not downloaded their report. If you click on the red part of the donut, the table below will populate with the managers who have not yet downloaded their report.  You could select all and then using this toggle, send them a note to download their report.  If I click to the middle table here, I can see who's logged in action plan. And I can of course filter by which dimension they've logged in on the far right. I can see action plan status.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Clicking above for different views of the table. If I select the managers tab, I can see activity of different managers. I can search by manager ID name or managers manager.  And then I can see when they first logged in. If they've downloaded when they've downloaded reports, how many actions they've logged and when they've last logged in.  Of course, all of this is downloadable to Excel with those that far right button.  If I click on action detail, I can see even more. I can see the manager name and then here's where I can see the dimension and item they're working on as well as the action plan they've logged.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide Video
text: Here, if you want to sort and filter by the item folks are working on, you could then, you know, download all the users working on the same thing in order to provide them similar resources or guidance.  Finally, at the top right, we'll move over to the help and guidance tab. Here's where you can retrieve any documents about how to use the tool or any templates that your organization has provided for action planning.  For any technical support, please email survey at org vitality.com. Thank you.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: At the top bar of the Org Vitality reporting portal, select the user whose results you want to view.
Step 2: View the selected user, for example, Talia Holiday.
Step 3: Expand Talia's hierarchy by pressing the arrow to the right to see each of the director reports underneath her.
Step 4: Build out the hierarchy by clicking the arrows under the individuals listed beneath Talia.
Step 5: Alternatively, type a name at the top to search for a specific manager you want to view.
Step 6: Once you select the desired level in the hierarchy, the Dashboard will populate.
Step 7: If your goal is to download your PowerPoint report, click Download Full Report. This action will download the report to your desktop.
Step 8: To filter by demographics, click Demographic Filter on the right. This will display various demographic options based on your HRAS file or feed.
Step 9: You can filter responses by using a combination of AND and OR between different variables. Ensure that the responses meet the minimum N for the Dashboard to populate with those responses.
Step 10: After selecting the data and filters, the Dashboard will display the scores.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: Scroll down to view the overview section, which provides a comprehensive set of data highlighting the overall highs and lows, strengths, and opportunities of your survey. This section helps you identify areas to focus on.
Step 2: Observe the boxes across the top representing different dimensions of the survey.
Step 3: Use the arrow on the right or left to navigate through these dimensions.
Step 4: Click on any dimension box to view detailed items related to that dimension. For instance, clicking on the "Capabilities" dimension will display all related items in the box below. This box will show the percentage of favorable responses, the response count, and any relevant comparisons.
Step 5: Hover over the percentage of favorable responses to see the number of favorable responses and additional comparison details. These comparisons might include trend comparisons, overall comparisons, or comparisons against specific business units, depending on your company's settings.
Step 6: Notice the color and symbols associated with each score in the survey results. Scores with no statistically significant difference appear in black text without arrows. A statistically significant increase is indicated by green text with an up arrow, while a significant decrease is shown in red with a down arrow.
Step 7: Understand what constitutes statistical significance in your data. For groups with over 100 participants, a difference of five points or more is significant. For groups of 50 to 99, the difference must be 10 points, and for groups smaller than 50, it needs to be 15 points. This scale adjusts based on group size, as smaller groups can cause more significant shifts in data.
Step 8: Check the right side of your screen to see the "Who Responded" section, which displays your response rate, response count, and head count.
Step 9: Evaluate whether your survey's response rate is adequate. A response rate above 75% is generally considered good and statistically representative of your organization's population.

text:
Step 1: Access the report to gauge your baseline performance, ensuring it meets at least the minimum N5 criteria. From here, begin building out various modules to further analyze your data.
Step 2: Identify the most favorable items within your report. These items display as percentages, showcasing areas of strength in either favorable, neutral, or unfavorable terms. Utilizing this information can provide a clear view of your overall strengths.
Step 3: Locate the most unfavorable items listed in your report. These represent key opportunities for improvement. Look for the three dots located in the top right corner of this section.
Step 4: Click on the three dots to access additional options. From here, you can download an Excel report of the data or take a screenshot of the data, which includes useful graphs for presentations.
Step 5: Continue scrolling to discover which areas have shown the most improvement. This section highlights where significant positive changes have occurred in your data.
Step 6: Review sections detailing what declined the most. If this part of the report shows 'insufficient data', it indicates a lack of significant decline in any items, meaning nothing relevant decreased during the period.
Step 7: Start building out the module on the left side of the screen, which helps determine where to focus your improvement efforts. It highlights specific areas requiring attention and suggests actionable steps.
By following these steps, you'll gain a comprehensive understanding of your data's strengths and opportunities, helping you make informed decisions for future strategies.

blocks.text: By following these steps, you'll gain a comprehensive understanding of your data's strengths and opportunities, helping you make informed decisions for future strategies.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: Analyze the three strategic items suggested by the algorithm based on your results. These items are selected not only based on their priority levels but also on the potential impact you can have on them.
Step 2: Click Start action plan to access the action tool, where you can manage and plan your strategies.
Step 3: In the action tool, review the three suggested items. You have the option to switch to all items if you wish to work on additional tasks.
Step 4: Select the top item to focus on and scroll down to view some sample action ideas.
Step 5: Click on a sample action idea. This will add it to your actions to address. Here, you can edit or draft a new action plan to tackle the selected item.
Step 6: Set a target completion date for the action. Ensure the date gives you enough time to complete the task effectively.
Step 7: Utilize the tool to set reminders for yourself, update the status of the action, and finally click save and finish.
Step 8: After saving, you have the ability to review and update any of your actions. If necessary, go back to edit the action or set new reminders.
Step 9: If you are a manager overseeing other managers, review the actions taken by your subordinates. You can view and sort actions in the table by manager name, the team member working on the action, the specific item, the action itself, the target date, and the status.
Step 10: Export the action details to Excel if needed for further analysis or reporting.
Step 11: Return to the dashboard to continue managing your tasks or to access other features.
Step 12: Explore the remaining features and tools available on the dashboard to enhance your management capabilities.

text:
Step 1: Understand the drivers of engagement, which are predictive of employee engagement within your organization. These drivers are universal but tailored to your specific organizational context. Review your organization's scores displayed on the dashboard to identify areas for improvement.
Step 2: Use the left side of the dashboard to select and view open-ended comments. Click on the comments you're interested in to read highlighted sections for the most actionable feedback.
Step 3: Get an overall sense of performance by reviewing the main dashboard. This provides a comprehensive view of how you're doing across various metrics.
Step 4: Explore the "Dimensions" section for detailed insights into specific areas like alignment. Click the down arrow next to a dimension such as alignment to view individual questions and their average scores. This helps you understand how the overall average score for a dimension is compiled.
Step 5: Navigate to the "Questions" tab to analyze responses to individual survey questions. Sort the questions by score, percent favorable, neutral, unfavorable responses, and compare trends over time or against benchmarks. Remember, a score of 75% favorable or higher generally indicates a strength, while 50% favorable or lower suggests an area for improvement, though this can vary depending on your organization and the specific topic. Focus on the most critical areas for your organization.
Focus on the critical aspects of your business when analyzing survey data. Let's explore how to effectively use the heat map and manage reports for better insights.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: Access the heat map which defaults to a hierarchy view. Initially, you'll see the organization overall and each of the CEO's direct reports on the left.
Step 2: Observe the color-coded scores on the heat map. Green indicates strengths, and red highlights opportunities. Note the arrows indicating significant trends.
Step 3: Expand any dimension to view specific questions within it if further detail is needed.
Step 4: To analyze data based on demographics, click on the demographic dropdown. For instance, select gender to slice the data by gender and compare the results.
Step 5: Use the three dots at the top right to download an Excel report or take a screenshot of the current data view.
Step 6: Visit the report library to access existing reports. Navigate to the top of the screen and select Manage Reports then Report Library.
Step 7: In the report library, search for a specific leader report by name. Download it by clicking the PowerPoint icon or view it on the dashboard by clicking the dashboard icon.
This guide will help you navigate through the data visualization tools and report management features effectively.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: Navigate to the "Create Custom Data Group" section to begin crafting a report. You'll be able to include or exclude various elements such as hierarchy levels, demographics, or specific survey items.
Step 2: Start by including Talia as a manager. Click on her name and drag it to the Included Managers section.
Step 3: Choose how you want to roll up the data. Options include normal rollup, directs only, roll up including manager, or individual. Ensure the combination you choose meets the minimum N requirement.
Step 4: Exclude any groups that might skew your data differently. For instance, drag Andy's name to the Exclude section if you want to exclude his group.
Step 5: Observe the total response counter located at the top right to verify the accuracy of the group you're building.
Step 6: Click on the Demographics tab on the left side of the screen.
Step 7: If you want to focus on high potential individuals, build out this category by dragging the group labeled 'Ready' into the Included Demographics section.
Step 8: Name your custom data group. Enter the desired name in the search bar at the top. For example, type "Talia minus Andy High Potential".
Step 9: Save your new data group by clicking Save. This action will redirect you to your data group library.
Step 10: Review all existing data groups in your library, including standard and custom groups you've created. You can sort these by type for easier navigation.
Step 11: Select any number of data groups by checking the boxes on the far left of each listing.
Step 12: Utilize the blue button at the top to export selected groups to Excel, share them with other users, or create a new report.
Step 13: Click Create Report to finalize your selections and start building your report based on the custom data group.

text:
Step 1: After navigating to the relevant screen, view the data groups you've previously selected displayed on the right side, and all available data groups on the left. If you wish to add more data groups to your report, simply click and drag them from the left to the right side.
Step 2: Select a data group to designate as your primary data group by checking the box marked "Primary."
Step 3: Assign a name to your primary data group.
Step 4: Save your settings by clicking the Save button.
Step 5: After saving, you'll be redirected to your report library, where you can view and manage all your reports. Here, you can sort reports by customer standard reports. If you select any reports on the left, you have the option to either download them or share them with other users in the tool.
Step 6: To support various actions, click Action Planning located at the top right of the screen.
Step 7: For new action planning, log an action for yourself or, if you are a manager or HR leader, for someone else. Click the down arrow under "Managing Actions for" and select another user to log an action for.
Step 8: Click Support Others to view and support action plans across the organization. The first dashboard shows overall metrics on activity within the organization.
Step 9: Review the dashboard titled "Report Downloads by Manager" to see who has or has not downloaded their reports.

source: Org Vitality Reporting Portal Guide
text:
Step 1: Click on the red part of the donut on the dashboard to view a list of managers who have not yet downloaded their report. This action populates the table below with relevant data.
Step 2: Use the toggle to select all managers in the list, then send them a reminder to download their report.
Step 3: Click on the middle table to view who's currently logged in and review their action plans. Here, you can filter the data by the dimension of their logged activities.
Step 4: Click on the Action Plan status at the top of the table to switch between different views.
Step 5: Navigate to the Managers tab to see detailed activity of various managers. You can search by manager ID, name, or their superior's name.
Step 6: In this tab, you'll find information such as the manager's first login, their report download history, the number of actions they've logged, and their last login date. All these details are downloadable to Excel using the button on the far right.
Step 7: Click on Action Detail for a more comprehensive view of each manager's activities.
Step 8: In the Action Detail view, you can see the manager's name and the specific dimension and item they are working on, along with their action plan details.
Step 9: If needed, sort and filter by the items managers are working on to group users who are focusing on similar tasks, enabling you to provide targeted resources or guidance.
Step 10: Move to the Help and Guidance tab in the top right corner to access documents and templates provided by your organization for action planning, or to seek technical assistance.
For any technical support issues, email surveyorgvitality.com.
